Poisson distribution with parameter m is given by the formula; p(X= x) = e^(-m) m^(x)/x ! ; x = 0, 1, 2, 3, …. . or for x = 0, 1, 2, 3, …. …. …, then e^(x) = x’ = 1, e, e^(2), e^(3), … … …, and the corresponding probabilities are listed as; e^(-m){ 1, m, m^(2)/2!, m^(3)/3!, …. … ..} . Therefore E(X) = e^(-m){0.1 + 1.m/1! + 2.m^(2)/2! + 3.m^(3)/3! + …. …. .. }. = e^(-m) m { 1 + m/1! + m^(2)/2! + …. … ..} = m e^(-m) e^(m) = m . Next, let us come to the actual problem i.e. let us find E(e^(X)) . For that we can go as above way but an easier way will be as follows; We know that m.g.f. of a poisson variate X is given as M((t, X) = E(e^(tX)) = e^{m(e^(t)-1)} . Now, if we put t = 1 in the above, we get, M(1, X) = E(e^(X)) = e^(m(e-1)) . Which is the required answer of the problem.

You must add each value with its corresponding probability, since there are continues (infinite) values you must integrate. And after that divide by the infinite possibility values, another integral So if p(X) is the poission distribution then <e^X> = integrate(e^X * p(X))dx /integrate(p(X))dx As you can see, its nothing more than the average for getting your grades for example, only that it is continues The limits of the integral go from -infinite to infinite both.
